poem:
The Quiz

Old hands tremble  
with answers  
half-formed—  
  
Confidence swells  
like a gale,  
distorting true north.  
  
Each wrong word  
a clamor—  
misplaced certainty,  
  
Magnetic misdirection,  
drawn toward defeat,  
  
the haphazard hum  
of well-worn voices  
betraying wisdom  
as laughter rings.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "How not to be the most annoying person in a pub quiz – five things I’ve learned | Zoe Williams I am always considered likely to be a quiz asset, because I’m old, and yet I’m a huge quiz deficit – not only usually wrong, but with such confident delivery that I make others in the team, who are right, lose their way, like a magnet on a compass. After another stunning defeat, in which". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
